article_title: The Spanish-Moroccan War (1859-1860): The War of Tetouan

paragraphs.text: The Spanish-Moroccan War, also known as the War of Tetouan (الحرب الإسبانية-المغربية حرب تطوان), erupted in 1859, rooted in a complex history of Spanish-North African relations and Spain's desire to assert its influence in the region . Centuries of Christian-Muslim contact had left a cultural legacy in Spain, but also contributed to perceptions of Spain as backward . Spain's declaration of war in October 1859 was partly motivated by a desire to emulate the influence of France and Great Britain in Africa . Some in Spain saw the war as a new colonial project during a time of imperial collapse, offering a chance to vindicate Spain's perceived derision by north-western European powers and providing a sense of unity during a period of socio-political disunity .

The immediate trigger for the war was a border dispute near Ceuta, one of Spain's long-held presidios in North Africa . The Anyera tribe destroyed a boundary stone, leading to Spain's declaration of war on October 22, 1859 . This incident served as a pretext for Spain to pursue its broader colonial ambitions . The Spanish government, led by Leopoldo O'Donnell, sought to use a military victory to strengthen national sentiment and quell internal political instability .

Spain's war aims included restoring national honor, demanding guarantees, and seeking indemnification for damages . The Spanish army was organized into several corps, totaling 35,000 men . The intended target was Tangier, with a land-based operation planned from Ceuta through Tetouan . O'Donnell aimed to use a military victory to strengthen national sentiment and quell internal political instability .

England and France, with strategic and economic interests in the area, initially showed reluctance towards a possible Spanish intervention, preferring diplomatic solutions . However, Spain secured England's approval for the war by providing guarantees that Spanish actions wouldn't threaten British interests in the Strait of Gibraltar . The French ambassador in Madrid, Barrot, analyzed O'Donnell's strategies to gain political support and the role of the press in inciting national honor .

The Tetuan campaign occurred from October 1859 to March 1860 under adverse conditions . The Spanish army took five months to cover 42 kilometers with high human and economic costs . Key battles included Castillejos, Monte Negrón, Tetuán, Samsa, and Uad-Ras in early 1860 . Tactical superiority and the discipline of Spanish soldiers contributed to victories at Castillejos, M'nuel River, and Cabo Negro, securing the Tetuan valley . The capture of Tetouan on February 6, 1860, marked a turning point and demonstrated Spain's capacity to seize an important enclave .

sections.subtitle: The Treaty of Tetouan and its Consequences

paragraphs.text: The Treaty of Tetouan was signed on April 26, 1860 . It defined Ceuta and Melilla's borders, ceded Ifni to Spain, set a war indemnity of 20 million duros (400,000,000 reales or 100 million pesetas), and allowed Spain to occupy Tetouan as collateral until the debt was settled . Morocco struggled to make the indemnity payments, leading to increased taxes, a loan from Great Britain, and eventually Spanish control of customs revenues in several Moroccan cities from 1862 to 1884 . The war cost Spain 236 million reales .

The war and subsequent agreements weakened the power and autonomy of the Moroccan sovereign . The treaty also granted Spain land on the Atlantic coast near Santa Cruz la Pequeña for a fishing establishment and allowed Spain to establish a missionary house in Fez .

sections.subtitle: Impact on Spanish Society and Culture

paragraphs.text: The Spanish war on Morocco generated significant patriotic fervor in 19th-century Spain . The war was seen by some in Spain as a new colonial project during a time of imperial collapse . The war provided a sense of unity in Spain during a period of socio-political disunity . The war also raised interest in the Arab world, influencing orientalist literature and painting .

The war was the birth of war photography in Spain . Enrique Facio is identified as the pioneer photographer of the Hispano-Moroccan War (1859-60), and his work is analyzed . Pedro Antonio de Alarcón's war chronicles, 'Diario de un testigo de la Guerra de África', are used to relate illustrations to chronicles and establish photograph authorship during the 1859-1860 war .

The war also impacted Spanish military culture, contributing to a heroic inflection that persisted under the Franco regime . The Moroccan wars were generally unpopular in Spanish society, and anti-war sentiment served as a mobilizing factor for political parties critical of the Restoration .

sections.subtitle: Impact on Moroccan Society and Tetouan

paragraphs.text: The announcement of the war triggered discords among Tetouanis and revived conflicts between the city and the countryside . The fall of Tetouan is depicted as a new edition of the fall of al-Andalus in 1492 . The fall of Tetouan strengthened discords among Tetouanis and triggered 'male panic' . The Spanish war on Tetouan stirred concerns around masculinity, its reform, and the protection of male honor .
The Spanish occupation of Tetouan bolstered the ‘age of Moroccan reform’ . The occupation also led to the looting of Tetouan, often attributed to 'rural savages' .

The Hispano-Moroccan War had a significant effect on the Jewish community of Tetouan . The years 1859-1862 were of great importance for the Jewish community of Tetouan, due to the war . Before the declaration of war by Spain on October 22, 1859, many Jews departed from Tetouan, mostly to Gibraltar . Around 3,000 refugees from Tetouan and elsewhere fled to Gibraltar before and during the war .

The Spanish entered Tetouan on February 6, 1860 . Two days before the Spanish entry, uncontrolled elements attacked the Jewish quarter in Tetouan . The Jewish community initially considered the Spanish as liberators . A period of "good occupation" lasted for two years, ending on May 2, 1862 . After May 2, 1862, some Jews emigrated to Spain and more emigrated to Oran, due to fears of reprisals .

The discovery of the Sephardic community in Tetouan during the war brought their existence to the attention of Spanish society between 1860 and 1866 . Journalists were surprised and pleased by the "sincere love for Spain" shown by Moroccan Jews during the Hispano-Moroccan War .

The war inspired artistic works, including those by Marià Fortuny . Fortuny traveled to the war scene in Morocco in the first months of 1860 . He created hundreds of sketches of the war that he used later for his paintings . Fortuny's drawings included depictions of Muslim life, which inspired his orientalist art .
Pedro Antonio de Alarcón's war chronicles, 'Diario de un testigo de la Guerra de África', are used to relate illustrations to chronicles and establish photograph authorship during the 1859-1860 war .

The Spanish-Moroccan War of 1859-1860 had long-term implications for Spanish-Moroccan relations, contributing to ongoing antagonism between the two countries . The war also laid the foundation for modern Spanish colonialism in Morocco . The war and subsequent agreements weakened the power and autonomy of the Moroccan sovereign . The war was also a key event that shaped the Spanish imaginary of Tétouan .
